car-s-91.stu

Shift = 17	Min clashes = 10202	at step 1
Shift = 15	Min clashes = 2474	at step 802
Shift = 16	Min clashes = 2156	at step 3121
Shift = 14	Min clashes = 2186	at step 3024
Shift = 13	Min clashes = 2496	at step 1098
Shift = 12	Min clashes = 2334	at step 3101
Shift = 28	Min clashes = 2468	at step 2840
Shift = 56	Min clashes = 2228	at step 2982
Shift = 20	Min clashes = 2324	at step 1763
Shift = 18	Min clashes = 2504	at step 3798

then I thought that if we change the shifts for each course then the result would be better, because the courses wouldnt come and sit in the same place that often. so I changed the code
public void iterate(int shifts) {
		for (int index = 1; index < elements.length; index++) {
			elements[index].setForce();
			for (int move = 1; move <= shifts && elements[index].force != 0; move++) {
				elements[index].setForce();
				elements[index].shift(period);
			}
			shifts++;
		}
	}
and it worked

Shift = 17	Min clashes = 2448	at step 1
Shift = 56	Min clashes = 2426	at step 1
Shift = 18	Min clashes = 2494	at step 1
Shift = 15	Min clashes = 2418	at step 1

then I thought that maybe if shifts are not only incremented but decremented then the result would get better.
public void iterate(int shifts) {
		for (int index = 1; index < elements.length; index++) {
			elements[index].setForce();
			for (int move = 1; move <= shifts && elements[index].force != 0; move++) {
				elements[index].setForce();
				elements[index].shift(period);
			}
			if(index<elements.length/2){
				shifts++;
			}else{
				shifts--;
			}

		}
	}

and the results where
Shift = 17	Min clashes = 2304	at step 1
Shift = 18	Min clashes = 2294	at step 1
Shift = 15	Min clashes = 2344	at step 1
Shift = 14	Min clashes = 2312	at step 1
Shift = 13	Min clashes = 2326	at step 1

and here all the results were that it convereged right at step 1

then I tried with random
public void iterate(int shifts) {
		Random r = new Random();

		for (int index = 1; index < elements.length; index++) {
			elements[index].setForce();
			for (int move = 1; move <= shifts && elements[index].force != 0; move++) {
				elements[index].setForce();
				elements[index].shift(period);
			}
			if(index<elements.length/2){
				shifts = shifts+r.nextInt(2);
			}else{
				shifts =shifts-r.nextInt(2);
			}

		}
	}

Shift = 17	Min clashes = 2272	at step 1
but it wasnt that good

hec-s-92.stu

Shift = 17	Min clashes = 30	at step 1
Shift = 16	Min clashes = 10	at step 288
Shift = 15	Min clashes = 10	at step 187
Shift = 14	Min clashes = 8	at step 852
Shift = 13	Min clashes = 6	at step 736
Shift = 12	Min clashes = 10	at step 262
Shift = 24	Min clashes = 4	at step 393

with the updated code but it wasnt very optimal in this case => it works well with big data

Shift = 17	Min clashes = 20	at step 1
Shift = 16	Min clashes = 28	at step 1
Shift = 12	Min clashes = 30	at step 1
Shift = 24	Min clashes = 28	at step 453


Training

Shift = 17	Min clashes = 30	at step 1

9	4	0
10	4	0
11	2	0
12	3	0
13	2	0
14	3	0
15	4	0
16	2	0

Good cases that autoassociator is trained on
Slot Courses Clashes
1	8	0
2	6	0
3	8	0
4	4	0
5	10	0
6	5	0
7	6	0
8	4	0
9	4	0
10	4	0
12	3	0
14	3	0
15	4	0


hec-s-92.stu
trained matrix is 81x81(not including dummy) matrix with 11,12,13 values and 0 diagonal, in reality 11 cases are enough for n=81 => the network is trained

0 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 13 13 11 11 11 12 11 12 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 12 11 13 11 11 11 11 11 11 13 11 11 11 11 11 12 12 12 11 11 11 12 12 11 12 13 11 11 11 11 11 11 13 11 11 12 12 12 11 11 11 11 13 11 11 11 11 11
11 0 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 13 11 11 12 11 12 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 12 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 11 13 11 11 11 11 12 12 12 13 11 11 12 12 11 12 11 11 11 13 11 11 11 11 11 11 12 12 12 11 11 11 11 11 11 13 11 11 11

but we can continue to see patterns

Good cases that autoassociator is trained on
Slot Courses Clashes
1	4	0

16	5	0

trained matrix is 81x81(not including dummy) matrix with 18,19,20,21,22 values and 0 diagonal
